questions.text: 1. In an experimental study of insulin after glucose administration, blood glucose was brought to 300 mg/dL and maintained at that level. What will happen to insulin in this condition?

choices.text: Rapid increase in insulin initially and gradual decrease
Insulin increased inititally and maintained at that level

questions.solution:
The release of insulin after glucose administration is biphasic, in which insulin secretion increases initially and is maintained at that level.

After a rise in blood glucose to a level that is 2-3 times normal, there is a sudden increase in plasma insulin due to the release of preformed insulin. Since this preformed pool is limited, the peak insulin level is not sustained and gradually declines. With persistent hyperglycemia, insulin levels rise again, this time due to the secretion of newly synthesized insulin. This second phase is slower, more prolonged, and continues until a plateau is reached.

questions.text: 3. A young man traveled from Delhi to Leh, which is at 3700 m above sea level and started to experience dizziness, nausea, discomfort, and headache. Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for the symptoms?

choices.text: Increased HCO₃⁻ causing cerebral vasodilation leading to fluid leakage from the intravascular space
Decreased pO₂ causing cerebral vasodilation leading to fluid leakage from the intravascular space
Increased H⁺ causing cerebral vasodilation leading to fluid leakage from the intravascular space
Decreased pO₂ causing cerebral vasoconstriction leading to fluid leakage from the intravascular space

questions.solution:
The symptoms experienced by the patient can be explained by decreased pO₂, causing cerebral vasodilation, leading to fluid leakage from the intravascular space.

The patient's presentation is characteristic of acute mountain sickness (AMS), which is a neurological condition that appears 6-12 hours after going to a high altitude, resulting from reduced pO2. AMS is likely to be seen after an ascent to more than 2500 metres, but can also be seen at lower altitudes (1500-2500 m). It is mainly diagnosed based on symptoms such as headache, nausea, tiredness (discomfort), and dizziness, since there are usually very few physical signs. 

The low pO₂ leads to hypoxic cerebral vasodilation, which increases cerebral blood flow and raises capillary hydrostatic pressure. This, in turn, increases capillary permeability and causes fluid to leak into the brain tissues, producing symptoms such as headache, nausea, dizziness, and discomfort. This is known as high-altitude cerebral edema (HACE).

AMS minaly results from rapid ascent to higher altitudes and is best prevented by gradual ascent with time for acclimatization.

Mild AMS is managed by halting ascent, acetazolamide, and descent if needed. Moderate AMS requires descent, oxygen, acetazolamide or dexamethasone, and possibly hyperbaric therapy. HACE is treated with urgent descent, oxygen, and dexamethasone, while high-altitude pulmonary edema (HAPE) requires descent, oxygen, warmth, and nifedipine, with hyperbaric therapy if evacuation is delayed.

Other options:

Option A: Following ascent to high altitude, there is hyperventilation leading to the washout of CO2, causing respiratory alkalosis. To compensate, the kidneys reduce the excretion of H+ ions and increase the excretion of HCO3-. So a decrease in HCO3- concentration is seen instead of an increase.

Option C: Initially, hypoxia-induced hyperventilation lowers pCO₂, producing respiratory alkalosis with reduced H⁺ in blood and CSF. Later, renal compensation increases HCO₃⁻ excretion, bringing CSF pH back toward normal with a relative rise in H⁺ compared to the initial state. However, this change in H⁺ is not the cause of cerebral vasodilation, which is primarily driven by decreased pO₂.

Option D: Decreased pO₂ (hypoxia) induces cerebral vasodilation and not vasoconstriction. Hypoxia-induced vasoconstriction is seen in the pulmonary vasculature, leading to an increased pulmonary capillary pressure and development of pulmonary edema, also known as high-altitude pulmonary edema (HAPE).

Pearl PM1009: Acclimatization to high altitude

questions.text:
4. If there is zero filtration across the capillaries, then what is the interstitial hydrostatic pressure (Pi), given that:

Capillary hydrostatic pressure: 18 mmHg Capillary oncotic pressure: 27mmHg  Interstitial oncotic pressure: 7 mmHg
questions.solution:
The interstitial hydrostatic pressure (Pi) that results in net zero filtration across the capillaries is -2 mmHg.

The net filtration force across the capillary wall is determined by Starling’s equation:

Net force = (Pc - Pi) − ( πc - πi)

Where: Pc = capillary hydrostatic pressure = 18 mmHg Pi = interstitial hydrostatic pressure = ? πi = interstitial oncotic (colloid osmotic) pressure = 7 mmHg πc = capillary oncotic (colloid osmotic) pressure = 27 mmHg

Given that the net force is 0 (no net movement of fluid):

0 = (18 - Pi) − (27 - 7) Pi = -2 mmHg (option D)

The rate of filtration at any point along a capillary depends on a balance of forces sometimes termed Starling forces.

The two main forces are hydrostatic pressure and osmotic pressure. 

Hydrostatic pressure gradient: the difference between capillary hydrostatic pressure and interstitial fluid hydrostatic pressure. Interstitial fluid pressure varies with tissues: it is positive in the liver and kidneys and can be as high as +6 mmHg in the brain.

Osmotic (oncotic) pressure gradient: directed inward, and calculated as plasma colloid osmotic pressure minus interstitial colloid osmotic pressure. The plasma osmotic pressure is largely exerted by plasma proteins within the capillaries.

Pearl PM0287: Starling Forces

πi=interstitial colloidal osmotic pressure

πc=capillary colloidal osmotic pressure

questions.text: 5. The given graph shows pCO₂ and pO₂ of the right lung along with the ventilation and perfusion ratio. Which point on the graph represents the V/Q ratio if there is a complete block of the blood supply at the alveolar level of the right lung due to pulmonary embolism?
questions.solution:
Point 4 in the graph represents the V/Q ratio of this patient's right lung due to pulmonary embolism.

The ventilation-perfusion ratio (V/Q) is defined as the ratio of lung ventilation to pulmonary blood flow (perfusion) at rest. The average V/Q ratio in the lungs is approximately 0.8. Normal venous blood has a pO2 of 40 mm Hg and a pCO2 of 45 mm Hg.

If perfusion to the alveolus is blocked by an embolus (Q = 0), gas exchange cannot occur. Although alveolar ventilation remains normal (V > 0), there is no blood flow to allow diffusion. Thus, the V/Q ratio becomes infinite (since the denominator, Q, is zero), which corresponds to point 4 on the graph.



Other options:

Option A: Point 1 represents a V/Q ratio of zero (V/Q = 0), occurring when ventilation is blocked (V = 0) but perfusion remains (Q > 0). This is seen in the case of foreign body obstruction.

Option B: Point 2 corresponds to Zone 3 of the lung, where the V/Q ratio is the lowest.

Option C: Point 3 corresponds to Zone 1 of the lung, where the V/Q ratio is the highest.
